thread.title: 17-year-old charged with manslaughter in 2014 deaths of 2 high school basketball players
thread.title_full: 17-year-old charged with manslaughter in 2014 deaths of 2 high school basketball players | AL.com

author: Cassie Fambro | cfambro@al.com
title: 17-year-old charged with manslaughter in 2014 deaths of 2 high school basketball players
text:
Hannah Elizabeth Reed, 17, has been charged in the death of two south Alabama high school basketball players who died as a result of her erratic driving a year ago, according to Mobile County District Attorney Ashley Rich.
In addition to two counts of manslaughter, Reed, of Chunchula, is charged with third-degree assault, speeding in excess of 25 mph over the speed limit, reckless driving and improper passing.
Rich said the investigation was kept under wraps for a little over a year to gather enough evidence to present to a grand jury.
The September 2014 incident happened when the then 16-year-old Reed was driving on Coy Smith Road in Mount Vernon. It was just after 11 p.m., and no one was wearing a seat belt.
Rich said Reed was traveling in excess of 80 mph in a section of the road designated for a 40 mph speed limit.
She had three passengers: all of them high school basketball players.
"She was illegally passing and went to make a corrective action," said Rich.
That's when the 2007 Scion driven by Reed struck a tree head-on.
The two students who lost their lives were well-loved Citronelle High School basketball players Sedrick "Redbird" James and Wylan Lang.
A candlelight vigil was held to remember the players and grief counselors were on hand for weeks.
Reed was booked Monday morning and remains in jail.
Reed claims to go to the University of Alabama on social media; her name could not be found in a UA student directory for the present year.
